subtitle: Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Our topic today is first sight theory, how
we all use extrasensory perception every day
of our lives.
My guest is Jim Carpenter, a licensed clinical psychologist.
He has published over a hundred research articles,
book chapters and popular articles on parapsychology.
He is past president of the board of the Rhein
Research Center in Durham, North Carolina
and has served on the board of directors of the Parapsychological Association.
As you might imagine, he is the author of first sight theory and also author of the
book First Sight, ESP and Parapsychology in Everyday Life.
Jim is based in North Carolina and now I'll switch over to the internet video.
Welcome Jim.
I'm very happy to be with you today.
Very nice to be here, Jeff.
As far as I know, you are one of the, I don't
want to say oldest necessarily, but you've
been in the field of parapsychology longer, I
think, than any other living parapsychologist
of which I'm aware.
Maybe there are one or two exceptions, but I know your interest goes way, way back.
You were reading J.B.
Rhein's work when you were a high school student.
I was, I was and had a little bit of correspondence
with him in high school and came to Duke with
his, if not encouragement, at least permission
and been involved with that field ever since.
Now, if I remember rightly, he left Duke University
in 1964, so you were, you were there before
then.
Yes, actually I graduated in 63 and then kept
coming back summers, I was in one of a little
group of people that he sponsored to come back
for summer study while we were in graduate
school along with Rex Stanford and Chuck Honerden
and Bob Morris, those were my main colleagues
at that point.
Well, and they all made great contributions to the literature as have you.
I miss them all.
They're, they're all deceased now.
I know, I know, I miss them too.
But you're really part of that generation of people who, I guess it'd be fair to say,
were the original students of J.B.
Rhein.
Yes, yes, I certainly was.
And at the same time as you were getting trained
and doing research in parapsychology, you
developed a professional practice, you know,
I think of as a related field of clinical
psychology.
Indeed.
Yeah, I went to graduate school in clinical psychology and got the PhD and, and went on
and had an academic career in clinical psychology
for a while at the University of North Carolina
and then left that and went full-time into private practice.
But all along, I've kept up an involvement in, in parapsychology.
I came back, my wife and I came back to the
Durham area for me to teach at UNC after graduate
school, partly because it gave me the chance
to continue an involvement with the lab along
with my mainstream psychology profession.
And I know it must have felt a little bit
schizophrenic because for the most part, mainstream
psychology is, they're not even neutral about parapsychology.
They tend to be antagonistic more so than, let's say, physics.
Oh, yes, that's for sure.
And I remember someone said at one point that
hostility to parapsychology varies inversely
to the distance, or varies as a function of the distance from Durham.
And so coming back to Chapel Hill was right
in the center of the area where there's still
a lot of suspicion and hostility and yeah, it was a rough ride in that way in a lot of
ways, actually.
I had a lot, I got a lot of flack for maintaining that interest.
So you've managed to develop a career that balanced these two interests.
Clinical psychology is so closely related to parapsychology because both fields are
ultimately looking at the nature of the human mind itself.
Yeah, a common link for me is that both of them, the patient in therapy and the person
in a parapsychological experiment are both trying to discover a new meaning.
They're both trying to create something that in some ways shouldn't be createable.
The person in therapy is trying to in some ways
become a new person, the person in parapsychology
experiments trying to do something impossible because you're asking them to.
And of course, Freud and all the way back, a lot
of therapists have talked about parapsychological
observations in therapy and I've kept track
of that myself and that's been a rich journey
too because I've had a number of patients bring
in lots of interesting psychic experiences,
sometimes right part of the therapy itself.
Is it fair to say I believe that your own personal interest in parapsychology began
in childhood as a result of experiences that you had?
Well, yes, I think especially I became curious
about it because my mother had experiences
that were anomalous and she would tend to,
she had dreams that came true, she had visions
that predicted the future in remarkable ways,
she tended to know who was calling on the
telephone and so the family sort of took that
for granted and she was also a librarian for
a number of years in our little town in northern New Mexico.
So she would bring home all the J.B.
Rhine books which I ate up and along with
some of the books from Britain in that field.
So yeah, I started reading that in high school and became fascinated with it.
I also have to think that the theoretical work that you've done to some degree builds
on the work of Gertrude Schmeidler who was very insistent that ESP could be understood
as a normal psychological function.
Absolutely.
I go to some trouble to shout out Gertrude in that respect.
She made a wonderful contribution in that way.
Her theory of parapsychology was that psi is a psychological function and that's the
motto I followed in my own attempt to develop a theory.
So yeah, I'm very much in Gertrude's footsteps
along with some others, Rick Stanford and
those are the probably two main ones.
I think it would be correct if I were to try
and sum up the first sight theory that you've
developed in a nutshell.
It would be that we are all at a subconscious level using ESP all the time.
It's the very foundation of our normal consciousness.
Yeah, that's the assertion I want to make.
That's why it's called first sight theory.
It's modeled after research in subliminal
perception which I've puzzled over for years
following that literature because the obvious
connections to parapsychology kind of shout
out to you if you pay attention.
What we see in the subliminal perception literature
and psychology has come along only very gradually
and reluctantly to this understanding but it's pretty well established at this point
that every experience we have has an unconscious
history, that there are pre-conscious processes
that produce all of our experience and all of our behavior and that's understood often
just at a kind of impersonal biological level.
Those are brain events that are somehow causing
consciousness and that's true as far as it
goes but it's not actually an impersonal process because the whole thing is guided
by personal intentions.
Two people can be sitting in the same room in the same stimuli and their pre-conscious
processes are going to produce very, very
different streams of experience because they
have different histories and different intentions
in the setting and so I make the assertion
that every bit of experience, every bit of
behavior is preceded by pre-conscious processes
and these pre-conscious processes include always make reference to information beyond
the sensory sphere that we're privy to all of that.
I use Whitehead's term, pre-henchen, that the
unconscious mind prehens reality far beyond
the boundaries of the senses and makes use of that in every bit of experience that we
construct unconsciously.
And so, yeah, ESP and PK are consulted in
every act of behavior and experience but it's
all invisible and the theory also, I try to talk about how we so rarely have what seem
like psi experiences.
If this is actually going on all the time
unconsciously, why aren't we aware of everything
all the time?
And for the same reason, we're not aware of all the subliminal stimuli all the time.
For one thing, they're not experiences,
they're pre-conscious and they're unconscious.
So by their nature, they're not available to
experience but what we can see in the certain
situations is we can see the inadvertent expressions of these things.
That's how we know that a subliminal perception has occurred.
We never see it but we can, if we set the
experiment up correctly, we can see the effects
of having been exposed to a subliminal perception.
And that's exactly what we do in a parapsychology study.
We look at things that imply the target or imply the information.
This is true in remote viewing or Gansfeld or any parapsychological situation you want
to discuss.
And one implication of this, I'll just, I do
like your questions and I want to be guided
by them but I'll just say that one implication
of this is that we, in the past, since we
have thought of psi as a rare ability that maybe a few people have and they maybe have
it for a little while or they have it at certain
rare moments, if we think of it as something
that's actually going on all the time out of
sight, the whole function of an experiment
changes.
The rare ability idea, the function of an
experiment is to kind of set a trap and catch
this rare beast in our study.
From the first sight point of view, we're not trying to catch something that's rare.
We're trying to reveal the functioning of something that's going on all the time.
And so, first sight experiments tend to have
different, they tend to ask different kinds
of questions than experiments from other points
of view and they tend to look at different
expressions of psi than a lot of other experiments do.
There's so many questions I want to ask but to begin with, you mentioned psychokinesis
and I want to pick up on that because I had always assumed, and apparently incorrectly,
that first sight was a theory about extrasensory
perception and that psychokinesis was really
not part of the theory.
So perhaps you could explain a little bit how that would fit in.
Well, I do try to make it part of the theory.
I focus on ESP in my book because there's much more psychological research about ESP.
Most of the PK research has not been done by psychologists.
It's been done by physicists, engineers, people
who are interested in different kinds of questions.
And so there's not that much psychological literature.
And what I was trying to do in the book was
spell out the theory and also hold it up against
normal psychological findings in a number of different areas of mainstream research.
So I was focusing on where the psychology work is.
But yeah, in the theory, PK is considered first act.
In fact, the basic function of ESP, why do we have ESP, what's it for, is to help us
form the next best possible experience in this situation that I'm in at the moment.
The function of PK is to begin the optimal response to the situation that I'm in.
And the basic function of PK, as I propose,
is the link between my intention and my body.
And so when I say to myself in the morning,
it's time to get up, and I get up, what connects
my intention to my musculature by way of my brain is PK.
So the ordinary function of PK is to link intention and action in my own body.
Now sometimes, PK also exists outside the body, just like most experiences formed out
of immediate sensations, but sometimes it's
important to use information that comes from
somewhere beyond immediate sensations.
And then we see evidence of ESP.
And there are also times, and PK is ordinarily
restricted to my body and my sensations, but
there are also times when my action needs to actually happen out in the world beyond
my body, and then we see these remarkable instances where, in fact, something in the
world responds to my intention.
And so they're linked processes.
They work right together with each other, it seems to me.
I seem to recall J.B.
Rine raised that very point, that we use psychokinesis,
if I want to raise my hand like that as an
act of will, of course experimentally, that doesn't work too well because people will
say it's somehow normal, it's not paranormal.
Well, most of the expression of ESP and PK
is normal, and we never see it as anomalous.
It's just part of our normal experiencing and behaving.
It's only when you have a kind of unusual
expression of these things that we see, actually
all of this is going on beyond the body as well as within the body.
We don't see it beyond the body every minute, every day.
It's fairly rare for most of us, but there are times when we do see it.
I'm getting information way beyond my sensory sphere.
I'm having an effect in the world beyond
anything I can actually touch and manipulate.
And then we see that actually our prehending
interaction with the world is going on beyond
the body as well as within it.
It's just that all of that's unconscious and it's usually not seen.
The term you use prehending, if I understand
correctly, originated with Alfred North Whitehead.
His theories, he was a great philosopher.
I seem to recall in the J.B.
Rine's letters that Rine attended one of his
lectures, I think, at Harvard and referred
to him as a very ponderous person, almost impossible to understand.
So he did say that, yeah, yeah, right.
Rine was a very smart guy, but he wasn't exactly a philosopher.
And I think he probably didn't have the patience for somebody like Whitehead.
Yeah, I use Whitehead's term without all of
the implications the way he defines the term,
but I use it just because he pointed out that
it's a way of grasping reality that includes
both understanding and acting.
The prehending means I take in, it also means I take hold of.
And action, reception, experience, behavior,
all these things are mixed together at this
level and Whitehead also pointed out that
prehensions can be either conscious or unconscious.
So it's a very nice term for my purposes.
So there's a real distinction there between prehending and comprehending.
Yeah, because comprehending implies awareness.
And I'm saying that ESP is by its very nature forever outside of awareness.
Well then how can we have ESP experiences?
Well, I think we don't actually experience the ESP itself.
We experience derivative phenomena that issue from that.
And I could spell out what I mean by that.
And PK is the same thing if I'm in an emergency
situation of some sort and say a very meaningful
picture suddenly falls off the wall where
it's been very secure for years, then it isn't
that I've reached over and taken down the picture and put it on the floor.
I haven't carried out that behavior, but we link the picture falling to my intentions
and my experience because of what a meaningful coincidence it is.
And in fact, that could be a PK event.
That is, I could be prehending that picture,
which I'm doing all the time at some level,
and that picture falling at that moment could be expressing that fact.
It seems as though I might be jumping the
gun a little bit on your theory, but it seems
as if what it implies is something similar to the notion in physics of entanglement,
that everything is connected with everything else.
And at an unconscious level, of course, maybe
people have rare moments of what's called
cosmic consciousness where you feel like you're aware of everything all at once.
But most humans simply cannot sustain that level of awareness.
Maybe great psychics can do it briefly, but it seems as if that's a potentiality within
everyone.
Yeah, I think so.
I think it's an actuality within everyone at an unconscious level all the time.
I like to say that if ESP is so constant, where is it?
Where is it hiding?
And the answer to that is that it's hiding in every thought and every action.
And does this connect to the idea of entanglement and physics?
Well, maybe it does.
I'm not a physicist, but luckily we have some
very smart colleagues who are working hard
on that, so I'm always following what they're doing with a lot of interest.
And it may be that they can make some real headway in that way.
And of course, that'll be wonderful.
When I tell people I have a theory about parapsychology,
what they always want to know is, oh, well,
then you must be able to explain how the mind affects physical reality.
You must be able to deal with the mind-body problem.
And then I always have to say, no, I'm a psychologist.
This is a psychological theory.
And I think it's more important than the physical question.
And they say, well, yes, I feel sorry for
you, but you can explain why you believe that.
Well, the reason I believe that is that almost
all of our more robust findings in parapsychology
are psychological in nature.
That is, the psychology of the thing is essential.
And if the purpose of science is to increase
an understanding of part of nature, then let's
go where the action has been.
Let's go to the psychological science.
And that's why it's a psychological theory.
And I'm trying to develop ways to understand
better what these things are, how they work,
affect them, and ultimately make better use of them at a conscious level.
And I think it's the psychology of it that is going to allow us to have that kind of
practical understanding.
The physics of it is really interesting.
And physicists especially find that very compelling.
How does the mind interact with the physical universe?
You know, obviously that's a deep and important question.
But I don't really deal with that question.
I'm interested in predicting, understanding and
predicting when we're going to get expressions
of ESP and PK, whether they're going to be positive or negative, that is in a hitting
direction or in a missing direction, and how strong they're going to be.
Those are the things I think science of prayer psychology should try to do.
And that's why I've developed this theory,
to try to help us do that research to answer
those questions.
If I recall from what you said earlier, the paradigm experiment in psychology that is
foundational to your theory would be the work in subliminal perception.
I'll tell you a dream I had that actually led me to first sight theory.
And I think it's appropriate that it started
with a dream, since in first sight theory
I talk a lot about things like dreams.
In this dream, I'm in a stream, like you're in New Mexico.
This is like a New Mexico mountain, Rocky Mountain stream.
And I'm standing on a rock, and I jump to another rock, and then I'm looking around
and I figure out the next best rock to jump to, and I jump to that rock.
And then the thought occurs to me, oh, this is what ESP is for.
ESP is for getting to the next thought.
And I'm going to have to tell Richard about this.
Because Richard Broughton, who was a colleague
at that time, had had a PA presidential address
in which he said, what parapsychologists need
to do if they want to understand Psy is first
figure out what it's for.
And in the dream I thought, okay, I'm waking
up out of the dream at this point, and I'm
thinking, this is what Psy is for.
It's for moving the mind to the next thought.
Or in terms of PK, it's for moving our behavior to the next best behavior.
And I think it's, and all of that guiding, constructing process we see in subliminal
perception, a subliminal perception.
Perception primes something.
It doesn't give us an experience, but it primes certain classes of experience.
And when you look at the research in subliminal
perception and the research in parapsychology,
they use different terms because they developed
independently, but they're describing the
very same patterns.
A subliminal prime functions exactly the way
an ESP target functions in an ESP experiment.
And I spell out the various similarities.
I think what it shows is that all of our pre-conscious
processes, which include long-term memory,
all of what we think of as creativity, they
function with exactly the same patterns that
the parapsychologists have been finding.
And one thing I do in my theory is show that
you can take parapsychological findings and
map them on to research in memory or research in
subliminal perception or research in creativity.
And you'll find exactly the same patterns apply.
Likewise, you can take these much more developed
areas of research, memory, creativity, subliminal
perception, carry those patterns over and apply them to parapsychology and they work
just wonderfully.
Everything seems to be working kind of the same way at that unconscious level.
This would be a good time to introduce a concrete
example because it's rather abstract what
you've been saying so far.
Well, a concrete example of a subliminal prime,
I mean, I can talk about the way it's defined
in experiments, but in real life, presumably
subliminal primes are happening all the time.
They're flying around both of us right now as we sit and talk to screens.
But we're not aware of them because they're unconscious, they're subliminal.
And in fact, since we're highly focused on
what we're doing, I certainly am, I'm trying
to make sense and look to you and talk to you
and deal with the technology and so forth,
that I have a lot of focus.
And so subliminal primes, when my mind is
engaged in this kind of focus, are not actually
going to be affecting my behavior very much.
They're not going to be affecting my consciousness or my behavior very much.
When I'm in a highly focused, concentrated
state, I'm going to screen out almost everything
else.
And the same thing is true in parapsychology.
When I'm really focused, really concentrating,
the whole extraneous, much more of the world
becomes extraneous to my purposes and I make myself oblivious to it.
And I don't in any way express it.
In fact, if we tried to measure it, while
I'm focused like this, we would probably get
a sign missing measure.
We probably get a negative deviation.
How do we see if subliminal perception is going
on all the time, do you ever see it in real
life?
Well, we almost don't.
And I realize actually, it was one way that I did see it in my everyday life.
And that is when I first became a little hard
of hearing, and that was quite a while ago
now before I got hearing aids, I would, my level, my threshold for conscious awareness
of sound was different than most people's.
Some would have to be louder for me to hear
it than for most of the people I'd be talking
to.
And sometimes I'd find myself in a circle of
people and there'd be a conversation going
on and I would, something interesting would occur to me and I would say it.
And then one time I did this and I looked around and my daughter was rolling her eyes
as if to say, he's doing it again.
And what I was doing again was without knowing
it, I had reworded something that someone
else in the conversation had said a few minutes
before, but I hadn't consciously heard it.
Everybody else had consciously heard it.
And so they knew I was just repeating this earlier contribution.
But for me, it was a brand new idea.
For me, it had been a subliminal prime.
For them, it was a conscious experience.
For me, it was a subliminal prime.
And so I could catch myself in the act of expressing something that for me had been
subliminal and for other people there, it wasn't.
Because you were hard of hearing, it only came through at the subliminal level.
Subliminal means below the limit or level of conscious awareness.
I think some of our viewers may not know much
about the research on subliminal awareness.
I remember back in the 1970s reading a book, I
think by Norman Dixon, about the controversial
science of subliminal perception.
It reminds me, was it Richard Brown who wrote
a book called Parapsychology, The Controversial
Science?
Yes, he did.
Yes, he did.
And those books of Dixon's were wonderful and his research was really groundbreaking.
It's gone on, that whole field has developed
enormously since Dixon's day, but he made
wonderful contributions in developing that.
I got to meet Dixon one time and that was a treat.
Now, you mentioned an experiment to test first
sight theory would be different than a conventional
parapsychology experiment, so let's talk about that.
What would such an experiment be?
Well, first of all, we would probably look almost exclusively, we wouldn't ask people
to guess what a target is and we wouldn't ask people to try to make something happen.
We would set up a situation in which we would
look at what I call inadvertent behaviors
of different kinds and make the unconscious material important to them in some way and
then see while we're observing their behavior
if we can see allusions to the material.
And so, for example, one study I carried out
for a number of years, I had a number of studies
on subliminal perception research showing that
subliminal stimuli can influence interpersonal
behavior.
So, for example, if you subliminally flash
hostile material to people, angry, aggressive,
bloody, so forth, to people and then you put them
in a situation in which there's a confederate
who's behaving in an annoying way in the waiting room.
When you record your subjects and you see, you
count the times that they express irritation
or withdrawal or in other words, if any way
in which they express some kind of emotional
response to the irritating confederate.
And what we find is if we expose people subliminally
to hostile stuff before we put them in this
waiting room, they're going to be much more responsive.
They're going to get more irritable, they're
more aggressive, more withdrawn, whatever
their typical way of dealing with aggression is.
If they've been subliminally exposed to happiness
and flowers, they're going to be much less
responsive to this irritating person.
There were other studies that showed some
subjects material that had to do with cooperation
and working together and achieving things as
a group and so forth and other people just
had neutral stimuli.
And then we put them in groups and we have
ways to measure how readily cooperative they
are with some group project.
And we find that the people who've been pre-exposed
to their cooperative stuff are friendlier,
more cooperative, come up with ideas more quickly.
They participate in a more positive way.
The people who haven't had these exposures aren't quite so quick to do those things.
And so what we see is that the subliminal
stimuli have primed certain kinds of behaviors.
So that was the analogy for this project and
I had a kind of quasi-therapy group of friends
that met once a week for an hour and we would
have an unstructured hour of interaction.
And these people, most of them were therapists
and so often the interaction was pretty emotional
and lively and usually it was a lot of fun, it was kind of spontaneous and fun.
But in another town, we're in Chapel Hill,
and in Durham, at the Rhine Center, or FR&M,
a computer is selecting a picture.
And we know that that picture is being selected.
No one's looking at it, it's just selected as
a number that identifies one of 400 pictures.
And these pictures are arranged in sets of four.
So it's going to pick one of 100 envelopes and one of four pictures.
And so now the session has ended, we've had
our interaction, whatever we're going to do,
we call up and we get the number of the envelope.
So we pull the envelope and lay out the four pictures.
Then we go through the four pictures and say,
which of these pictures could have been a
kind of symbol of the session we had today?
In terms of the content and the mood and the
whatever about the picture, just associate
to these pictures, which is the most like
our session, the next most, and then all the
members rank them and then those rankings are averaged.
What we found was that the picture in Durham,
we were able to unconsciously pick up that
picture and express it in our behavior in the group, all unconsciously, to an extent
that we could identify the picture, pick it
out among the decoys to a highly statistically
significant degree.
So this is a study in which we see that nothing paranormal is obviously going on.
We're just having a discussion among friends
that gets fairly emotional and lively sometimes.
And yet this, we also all have the intention
in the back of our minds that we'd like to
be expressing this target if we can, but we have no idea what the target is.
We're just kind of open to that intention.
And in fact, we do.
We do enough that we can pick the right
picture out much more than we should by chance.
And there's some meaningful sub-relationships here too.
For example, we rated the qualities of these sessions.
And I said that since my focus right now is
kind of clear and focused because I'm trying
to make sense talking to you, I'm going to be screening out most of reality.
What I'm going to let in to forming my thoughts
and my words is going to be a much narrower
band than if I'm just sitting around daydreaming
or if I'm playing or doing something creative.
I'm painting a painting.
Well, these groups tended to be very playful,
but sometimes they would get very serious
and emotional and when we rated the groups in terms of how intensely meaningful they
were, how revealing people were, how emotional
they were, we found that in the groups that
were doing the hardest emotional work, the side disappeared.
We weren't able to, we weren't expressing the pictures at those times.
On the other hand, on the sessions that were
very playful and light and not so serious
and not so focused, we expressed the picture a
lot, which makes sense in terms of my theory.
Because that's exactly how subliminal perception works.
It's actually how memory works.
So that's an example of a study from a first sight point of view.
Now, let me ask a few questions just to clarify the mechanics of the study.
First of all, when a picture is exposed in a
normal experiment on subliminal perception,
it might be flashed on a screen for a
hundredth of a second or something like that.
Right.
But in this case, since the stimulus is of
a parapsychological nature, it's not flashed
on a screen at all, not even for a millionth of a second.
So it's chosen at random using, I presume, a random event generator.
Is it chosen in advance of your session or afterwards?
During.
It's chosen right in the middle of the session by a random process.
And then the decoy pictures, you're presenting the group with four pictures.
One of them is the actual target.
Three others are decoys out of a larger pool
of, I think you said 400 or something like
that.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Yes, there's zero sensory exposure, so it's a subliminal perception of zero intensity.
All it is is it's a meaning.
It's an intention we have of getting what the computer is saying is going to be the
right picture.
That's all there is, is just that intended meaning.
And that orients us to the picture, and the picture gets expressed.
And at the end of the day, you're going to run this through the standard statistical
evaluations that are used in any behavioral science study.
Yeah, exactly, exactly.
For example, one day we were doing a Gestalt
therapy exercise, and one person was walking
around the room, and somebody else says, do something now.
And so, he goes behind this bald-headed guy, and he rubs his head.
Well, our target that day was a bull that
was bald with a big circle, and we're seeing
the bull from above, and the head's very prominent,
and there's a big circle on his head and an
X in the middle, like target.
That was one kind of funny example.
Another time the group was rather sad, someone
important to a couple of the members that
